Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. Thus, the NWFP needs to be complemented by policies that promote the development of older forests. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two most difficult to study in quantum systems. Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. We argue that the same mechanism may be at work in both contexts. Our results suggest that the origin of observers may be intimately connected to the origin of thermodynamic disequilibrium.
